conclusion: Determine which container, E or F, the liquid will flow into after passing through baffles from points A, B, C, and D.
Understand the setup with four input points: A, B, C, and D, each with their own colored paths connecting to either E or F.
First image shows labeled parts A through F, with points A, B, C, and D at the top and E and F at the bottom, and red arrows pointing from A, B, C, and D down towards E and F.
Second image shows blue droplets or flows coming from A, B, C, and D directed towards E and F, with some merged flows.
Third image shows detailed flow paths with different colors, including droplets merging and splitting.
Track the path of each input flow from A, B, C, and D to see where they end up, considering diagonal baffles.
Input A (Blue) in the first image has a red arrow pointing directly to E.
In the second image, the blue flow from A goes straight down to E without deviations.
Input B (Red) in the first image has a red arrow pointing to E.
In the second image, the red flow from B merges with the blue flow from A and goes towards E.
Input C (Yellow) in the first image has a red arrow pointing to E.
In the second image, the yellow flow from C merges with the red flow from B and the blue flow from A, all heading towards E.
